answers.answer: Hello,sorry for slow response to you.The way to control blood sugar is through eating a low carb diet (if you have a meter you can test after eating to see which foods work and which don't), exercise, and ensuring your weight is optimal.    With all of these, then you may be able to reduce your a1c, particularly if you are type 2 (and delay onset of diabetes for as long as possible).Type 2 is usually associated with insulin resistance.  At least in the beginning there is plenty of insulin, but it is not working very well.Type 1 is autoimmune type.  It is due to poor production of insulin /  absence of insulin. Many with type 1 may have antibodies, which can be tested for.  Other markers that may alert a doctor on the type of diabetes are; diabetes with thin body and athletic lifestyle, no family history of diabetes.  In adults type 1 diabetes can be sudden onset or slow onset.

As your pancreas is still producing insulin, but your body is not able to utilise it properly, you have Type 2 Diabetes.  In Type 1 Diabetes, the pancreas does not produce any insulin or not enough.Speak to your doctor and he/she will be able to confirm which type you have.A reading of 98 mg/dl is 5.4 mmol/lBlood glucose typically varies from 4 mmol/L to 6 mmol/L for people without diabetes.What you experienced is what is called hypoglycaemia.  What this means is that your sugar levels dropped too low.  You will have learned now, by experience, that you must eat regularly and not go for long periods without food.  You need to eat small amounts and more often.  Avoid highly processed foods and sugary foods (unless you are experiencing a hypoglycaemic attack).Eating foods that are classed as complex carbohydrates is much better than processed and refined foods.  The complex carbs break down more slowly in the body and will not give you a high surge of a sugar spike with a drastic drop.Don't forget that if you monitor your sugar levels my using a glucose meter, your sugar levels will also vary depending on which time of the day you take the test and what you have eaten and how much energy you have burned through exercise.The HBA1C blood test gives an average reading over a period of approximately 3 months.  This is because the sugar sticks to the red corpuscles and these are renewed approximately every 3 months.Hope this helps.Best wishes.
